children.title: God, the Son
children.comment: The co-equal and co-eternal Son of the Father, who became incarnate in Jesus Christ for the redemption of the world. Scripture stresses both the divinity and the humanity of the incarnate Son of God, and the necessity and total sufficiency of his atoning death for human redemption. Through his resurrection and ascension, he interecedes for believers at the right hand of God.

children.title: Jesus Christ, anger of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's controlled emotion arising from his unswerving opposition to evil and his determination to eradicate it.

children.title: Causes of Jesus Christ's anger
Petty legalism in religious observance
Attempts to prevent access to him
People leading others into sin
Demonstrations of Jesus Christ's anger
Purging the temple
Cursing the fig-tree
Jesus Christ's words in anger
Against demons
Against disciples
Against Pharisees
Against unbelief
Against false prophets
Against the rich
Against unrepentant cities
Jesus Christ reflects the anger of God
The anger of the glorified Christ
Against the unbelieving world
Against the wayward church
Jesus Christ, authority of
children.comment: The right of Jesus Christ to speak and act on his Father's behalf in forgiving sin, pronouncing judgment and promising eternal life to those who believe in him.

children.title: Jesus Christ's authority underlines his divine status
The origin of Jesus Christ's authority
It is given by God the Father
It is limited by the Father
It is questioned by others
The authority of Jesus Christ is seen in his works
He has authority over nature
He has authority over sin
He has authority over sickness
He has authority over evil
He has authority over death
The authority of Jesus Christ is seen in his teaching
Jesus Christ claims authority for his own words

seealsos.comment: The use of the phrase ``I tell you the truth'' emphasises Jesus Christ's authority
The ``I am'' sayings in John's Gospel emphasise the divine nature of Jesus Christ's authority

children.title: His authority is recognised by others
His authority is questioned and opposed by others
Jesus Christ delegates his authority to others
His followers preach in his name
His followers continue his works
His followers pronounce his forgiveness and judgment
The results of Jesus Christ's authority
He receives honour and glory
He arouses amazement
He is opposed
He is feared
His disciples are opposed
The authority of the exalted Christ
He is Lord
He is Lord of creation
He is Lord of the church
He is judge
He is Saviour
He is interceder
Jesus Christ, compassion of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's pity and loving concern for the lowly and the needy. His words and deeds show God's merciful and gracious nature in action.

children.title: Jesus Christ shows the compassion of God
The compassion of Jesus Christ is the basis of Christian confidence

primaryrefs.comment: The Greek word here translated ``sympathise'' has the sense of ``be compassionate towards''.

children.title: The demonstration of Jesus Christ's compassion
In supporting the weak
In healing the sick
In comforting the bereaved
In feeding the hungry
In finding and forgiving lost sinners
In giving rest to those who are burdened or abandoned
Jesus Christ's compassion is a model for Christians to follow
Jesus Christ, divinity of
children.comment: The equality and identity of Jesus Christ as God is clearly stated in the NT, and is also implied by the words and deeds of Jesus Christ. The OT prophecies also point to the divinity of the coming Messiah.

children.title: The NT writers affirm Jesus Christ's divinity

seealsos.comment: NIV footnote has alternative translations: ``Christ who is over all. God be for ever praised!'' Or: ``Christ. God who is over all be for ever praised!''

children.title: Statements which imply Jesus Christ's divinity
Jesus Christ's unity with the Father and the Holy Spirit in the Godhead
Jesus Christ's eternal nature indicates his divinity
Jesus Christ precedes creation
Jesus Christ is everlasting
Jesus Christ's pre-existence indicates his divinity
Jesus Christ's manifestation of God's glory indicates his divinity
Jesus Christ's divinity in the OT
The divinity of the coming Messiah
NT passages which apply OT passages about God to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's claims to divinity
He claimed to be one with the Father
He demonstrated his authority to forgive sin
Jesus Christ's actions imply his divinity
Jesus Christ's resurrection confirms his divinity
Jesus Christ's names and titles point to his divinity
Jesus Christ as judge

primaryrefs.comment: In the OT, final responsibility for judgment is assigned to God.

children.title: Jesus Christ as ``I am''

primaryrefs.comment: ``I am'' is the meaning of God's name in the OT (see Ex 3:14).

children.title: Jesus Christ as Saviour

primaryrefs.comment: According to the OT, God alone can save.

children.title: Jesus Christ as Lord

primaryrefs.comment: ``Lord'' was equivalent to God's name in the OT.

children.title: Jesus Christ as creator
Jesus Christ as shepherd

primaryrefs.comment: ``Shepherd'' was a well-known OT name for God.

children.title: Those who recognised Jesus Christ's divinity
The disciples
The demons
The consequences of recognising Jesus Christ's divinity
Jesus Christ is worshipped as God

primaryrefs.comment: The fact that no-one but God may be worshipped is fundamental to Judaism.

children.title: Prayer is addressed to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ, faithfulness of
children.comment: The total reliability and constancy of Jesus Christ is shown in his personal character, and made known by his words and works.

children.title: Jesus Christ's faithfulness is seen in his character
He is faithful by nature

primaryrefs.comment: A description of the exalted Christ.

children.title: The promised Messiah is faithful
Jesus Christ is faithful because he never changes
Jesus Christ is faithful because he is the truth

primaryrefs.comment: ``grace'' and ``truth'' are often associated in Hebrew with love and faithfulness.

children.title: Jesus Christ's faithfulness demonstrated in his obedience
He is faithful to his Father
He kept faithfully to his work
Jesus Christ's faithfulness is seen in his words
In his predictions about events

primaryrefs.comment: This prediction could refer to either Jesus Christ's transfiguration or his ascension
This prediction was fulfilled in A.D. 70 when the Romans destroyed Jerusalem and the temple.

seealsos.comment: finding a donkey and her colt
Jesus Christ's betrayer
Peter's denial

children.title: In his promises about eternal life
In his promise of authority for believers
In his promise about the Holy Spirit
Jesus Christ's promises about the future are faithful
Jesus Christ is faithful to believers in all circumstances
Jesus Christ, glory of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's radiance and splendour reflects the glory of the Father, and is both revealed to and reflected in the lives of believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's glory existed before the incarnation
Jesus Christ's glory is God's glory
God's glory is reflected in Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: John makes no distinction between God's glory revealed in Isa 6:3 and the glory of Jesus Christ

children.title: Jesus Christ brings glory to his Father
The Holy Spirit glorifies Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's glory is revealed on earth
Through his miracles
To his disciples
In his death and resurrection

primaryrefs.comment: One of the major themes of John's Gospel is that Jesus Christ is glorified through his death and resurrection.

children.title: The glory of the exalted Christ
His appearance
He receives glory from all creation
Jesus Christ's glory will be revealed at the second coming
Jesus Christ's glory is shared by believers
As they become like him
At the end of time
Jesus Christ, grace and mercy of
children.comment: The qualities of Jesus Christ by which he is compassionate, accepting and generous. In his ministry, Christ demonstrates these qualities towards those whom he encounters. Believers should model themselves upon Jesus Christ in this respect.

children.title: The grace and mercy of God made known in Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ shows the grace of God in his life.

children.title: Grace and mercy in the ministry of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ responds to pleas for mercy
His teaching reflects his grace and mercy

seealsos.comment: the parable of the unmerciful servant
the parable of the good Samaritan

children.title: Grace and mercy in relation to salvation
The grace of Jesus Christ
The mercy of Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: Paul speaks about his persecution of the Christians prior to his conversion experience.

children.title: Eternal life is a gift of grace and mercy
The grace and mercy of Jesus Christ and the Christian life
The need to rely upon the grace of Jesus Christ
Prayers for the grace of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ, holiness of
children.comment: The holiness of Jesus Christ is seen in his divine nature and work, as he stands apart from and above the created world with divine power, authority and purity. Recognition of the holiness of Jesus Christ leads both to a realisation of sin and unworthiness and to worship and adoration.

children.title: The holy character of Jesus Christ
Its divine origin
Its divine nature
Its divine purity
Its divine power
The holy work of Jesus Christ
He is set apart as God's servant
His life is consecrated to the will and purpose of God
He is appointed as the judge of sinners
He makes God's people holy
Declarations of the holiness of Jesus Christ
Results of recognising the holiness of Jesus Christ
Awareness of sin and unworthiness
Fear
Adoration and worship
Jesus Christ, humanity of
children.comment: Scripture stresses the total humanity of Jesus Christ. Although sinless, Christ shared in the general condition of humanity, including suffering and death.

children.title: Jesus Christ was a man
By his own claims
In statements made by others

seealsos.comment: the centurion
the Pharisees and teachers of the law
some Jews

children.title: Jesus Christ shared in the general condition of humanity
He assumed human nature

primaryrefs.comment: ``flesh'' here speaks not only of a material body but also of human nature.

children.title: He had a human descent
He had a normal body which could be handled and touched
He had a soul
Jesus Christ partook of human experience
He was born
He grew and developed
He was hungry
He was thirsty
He was tired
He slept
He was tempted
He suffered
He died

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ most closely identified with the rest of humanity through his death. However Jesus Christ is distinct from human beings in that his death was an act of free will and not the inevitable consequence of sin (see Jn 10:17-18).

children.title: The risen Christ has human characteristics
The returning Christ retains his human identity
Jesus Christ was a sinless human being

primaryrefs.comment: Sinlessness does not make Jesus Christ less human. It is sin that degrades humanity.

children.title: The necessity of Jesus Christ's humanity
As a man Jesus Christ made atonement for sin
As a man Jesus Christ gives the gift of resurrection
As a man Jesus Christ is able to help others in their need
As a man Jesus Christ is the perfect example
Jesus Christ, humility of
children.comment: The obedient submission of Jesus Christ to his Father, seen in his willingness to become a human being for humanity's sake, his freedom from self-interest and his willingness to serve others.

children.title: Jesus Christ's willingness to become a human being

primaryrefs.comment: ``human likeness'' is not mere similarity to but identity with humanity.

children.title: Jesus Christ's humility predicted in the OT
The poverty of Jesus Christ's birth and upbringing

secondaryrefs.comment: Only the poorest families offered doves or pigeons.

children.title: Jesus Christ's obedience to his human parents
Jesus Christ's obedience to his heavenly Father
Jesus Christ's dependence on his heavenly Father
Jesus Christ's submission to baptism
Jesus Christ's humble acceptance of ill treatment
Jesus Christ's acceptance of the cross
Jesus Christ's humility with other people
Jesus Christ's servant attitude
Jesus Christ's teaching about humility
Jesus Christ's humility as a model for others
Jesus Christ, joy of
children.comment: Jesus Christ brings joy to his people, who are able to rejoice at the coming of their Saviour and Lord, and all the benefits which he brings to them.

children.title: Jesus Christ's joy originates in God
From his intimate relationship with his Father and the Spirit
From his awareness of God's purposes
Jesus Christ's coming brings great joy
His birth
His resurrection and ascension
Jesus Christ gives joy to his people
He brings joy to his disciples
Being in his presence is likened to the joy of a wedding
To know Jesus Christ brings great joy to others
Jesus Christ, justice of
children.comment: The teaching and lifestyle of Jesus Christ show him to be just and impartial in his judgments and dealings with people. At the end of the age, God has appointed Jesus Christ to judge and rule with justice.

children.title: Justice was a quality displayed in Jesus Christ's life
Jesus Christ was just and impartial in his dealings with people

secondaryrefs.comment: with tax collectors and those classed as ``sinners''

children.title: Justice in the teaching of Jesus Christ
Parables which teach justice
Jesus Christ will judge the nations with justice

seealsos.comment: a Messianic psalm

children.title: Jesus Christ will rule the nations with justice

seealsos.comment: This prophecy refers to the Messianic age when Jesus Christ will rule the world as king

children.title: Jesus Christ, knowledge of
children.comment: Jesus Christ has perfect insight into God's purposes and into human nature by reason of his intimate relationship with the Father, but he has accepted limited knowledge as a consequence of his humanity.

children.title: Jesus Christ's knowledge of his Father
Jesus Christ's complete knowledge
Jesus Christ's foreknowledge of events
Jesus Christ's knowledge of his mission
Jesus Christ's knowledge of his death and resurrection
Jesus Christ's knowledge of his betrayer
Jesus Christ's knowledge of the disciples' desertion and Peter's denial
Jesus Christ's knowledge of human beings
Jesus Christ knows every human heart
Jesus Christ discerns evil thoughts and motives
Jesus Christ knows those whose faith is not genuine
Jesus Christ knows people's situations and needs
Jesus Christ's knowledge of believers
Jesus Christ knows those who are his
Jesus Christ knows those who call on him in faith
Jesus Christ knows believers' deeds
Jesus Christ knows believer's needs
Jesus Christ knows his disciples' misunderstandings and disputes
Jesus Christ knows those who are half-hearted
Jesus Christ's knowledge of the Scriptures
Limitations of Jesus Christ's knowledge
Jesus Christ acquired knowledge by usual human means
Things that Jesus Christ did not know on account of his humanity
Jesus Christ, love of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's total giving of himself, shown supremely in his obedient suffering and death on the cross, reveals God's amazing love for sinners. It continues to motivate and inspire Christians today.

children.title: The supreme quality of Jesus Christ's love
It caused him to leave his eternal glory
It moved him to give his life for others
He loves sinners
He loves each believer
Examples of Jesus Christ's love
His compassion for the needy
His love for children
His love for his mother
His love for his followers
Jesus Christ's love stems from the Father
He receives the Father's love
His love reveals the Father's love
Jesus Christ's love motivates the church
His love indwells believers
His love disciplines believers
His love inspires authentic Christian attitudes
His love inspires Christian marriage
His love inspires a desire for spiritual gifts
His love motivates Christians to live for God
Jesus Christ, majesty of
children.comment: The glorious splendour of Jesus Christ's royal authority belongs to him by right and is reaffirmed through his exaltation to the Father's right hand.

children.title: Jesus Christ shared in God's majesty before time began
Jesus Christ renounced his majesty to become a human being
Jesus Christ's majesty seen in his earthly ministry
At the transfiguration
At the entry into Jerusalem
Jesus Christ's majesty is reaffirmed through his exaltation
Jesus Christ is exalted to the throne of God's majesty
A vision of the glorified Christ in his majesty
Jesus Christ's is majestic in his absolute pre-eminence
Jesus Christ's majesty is shown by his authority as judge of all
All humanity will see Jesus Christ's majesty
Jesus Christ, mind of
children.comment: The centre of Jesus Christ's thought, understanding and motivation, characterised by a total dedication to God. Christians are called upon to have the same mind as Christ.

children.title: The intellectual capacity of Jesus Christ's mind
In childhood
In adulthood
Jesus Christ's mind was pure

primaryrefs.comment: The purity of Jesus Christ's mind is declared by his words and actions and by his oneness with God.

children.title: Examples of Jesus Christ's use of his mind
In overcoming temptation
Against opposition
Jesus Christ's mind is more than intellect
His thinking is supported by prayer
His thinking is tempered by understanding
His mind experiences anguish
Jesus Christ's mind is extraordinary
He has unusual insight
He understands the future
Jesus Christ's mind did not know all things
Jesus Christ's strength of mind made him resolute
Jesus Christ's mind was not always understood
Christians should have the same mind as Christ
In his attitude
In his knowledge of Scripture
In his awareness of God
In the love in which Jesus Christ's mind is exercised
Jesus Christ, obedience of
children.comment: The selfless obedience of Jesus Christ to the will of God his Father, through which the redemption of humanity is accomplished. Christ also shows himself willing to submit to earthly authorities and sets an example which believers are called to imitate.

children.title: Jesus Christ was totally obedient to his Father's will
Obedience was central to Jesus Christ's life and thought
Jesus Christ's obedience meant ultimate personal cost
Jesus Christ's obedience was necessary for God's salvation plan
Jesus Christ's obedience was shown in his human relationships
He was obedient to his parents
He was obedient to secular authorities
He was obedient to the Jewish law

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's obedience and commitment were to the spirit of God's law; his attitudes to Jewish legalism were often seen as disobedience.  Disputes over the Sabbath are one example.

children.title: Believers should follow Jesus Christ's example of obedience
Obedience to God's will is paramount
Christlike obedience expresses love for God
Obedience should characterise believers' lives

primaryrefs.comment: ``obedience'' refers to a whole lifestyle arising from a relationship with God through Jesus Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ, patience of
children.comment: Jesus Christ supremely displays God's patient character in his work of salvation. The patience of Jesus Christ is seen in his relationships with people and in his perseverance through trial and suffering to death. Followers of Christ are called to demonstrate patience in all their relationships and circumstances.

children.title: The patience of Jesus Christ in his earthly ministry
His patience with people
His patience with God's timing of events

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's life was lived under the shadow of the cross. He was concerned that people should understand his ministry and therefore he exercised great patience, being directed by the Father in the priorities and timing of his ministry.

children.title: His patience in suffering
Jesus Christ reflects God's own patient character
Jesus Christ's patience brings about God's salvation
Jesus Christ's patience must be appropriated by his followers
In relation to people
In enduring life's circumstances and sufferings
In communicating the gospel
In living and waiting for the Lord's coming
Examples of Jesus Christ's patience found in his followers
Jesus Christ, perfection of
children.comment: Jesus Christ perfectly radiates the glory of God, exactly representing his Father's likeness. Christ's work is complete and he is free from all impurity.

children.title: Jesus Christ represents perfection and absoluteness
His perfection was established through obedient suffering
All things find fulfilment in Christ
Jesus Christ radiates God's glory

seealsos.comment: At the transfiguration Jesus Christ's face mirrors God's glory and purity

children.title: Jesus Christ exactly represents the Father's likeness
The fulness of God dwells in Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's work is totally complete
Christians will finally participate in Christ's perfection
Jesus Christ is without impurity
Jesus Christ, power of
children.comment: The historical and ongoing effective authority of Jesus Christ over natural elements, over human life and ultimately over sin, forces of evil, Satan and death.

children.title: Jesus Christ's power is from God
God's creative power is exercised through Jesus Christ
God's infinite power is given to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's power is revealed on earth
Jesus Christ's power over nature
Jesus Christ's power over sickness
Jesus Christ's power over human life
Jesus Christ's power over his own life
Jesus Christ's power over human behaviour
Jesus Christ's power over forces of evil
Jesus Christ has power over sin and death
Jesus Christ's crucifixion defeats the power of sin
Jesus Christ's resurrection defeats the power of death
Jesus Christ's power over sin and death remains effective
Jesus Christ's power remains available in human experience
Jesus Christ's forgiving power is effective today
Jesus Christ's enabling power is effective today
Jesus Christ, pre-eminence of
children.comment: Jesus Christ excels over all of creation and reigns supreme over everthing in the created order.

children.title: The scope of Jesus Christ's pre-eminence
Over all people
Over his enemies

seealsos.comment: Paul probably interpreted ``captives'' to refer to the spiritual enemies of Christ defeated at the cross.

children.title: Over every power and authority
Over all traditions and institutions
Over all things
The pre-eminence of Jesus Christ in relation to others
To other prophets
To the patriarchs
To Aaron and other high priests
To angels
To other lords and kings
Descriptions of Jesus Christ's pre-eminence
He is the head
He is the capstone

primaryrefs.comment: By so saying Jesus Christ applied this verse to himself. The capstone/cornerstone was the most significant stone of a building's structure.

children.title: He is the Chief Shepherd
The reasons for Jesus Christ's pre-eminence
His divine origin
His equality with the Father
His authority derives from the Father
He possesses the rights of the firstborn

primaryrefs.comment: As the firstborn son has the rights and privileges of an heir, so Jesus Christ is heir of all things by virtue of his pre-existence and sonship.

children.title: He has a superior name
He is the First and the Last

primaryrefs.comment: This title implies that all things are summed up in Christ and find their purpose in him.

children.title: Examples of events whereby Jesus Christ's pre-eminence is recognised
His entry into Jerusalem
His resurrection
His exaltation to the Father's right hand
Jesus Christ, righteousness of
children.comment: Jesus Christ pleased his Father perfectly in his life on earth and in his death. He now gives believers a new status before God and a new power for living.

children.title: The promised Messiah will be righteous
The promised Messiah will establish righteousness
Jesus Christ's own righteousness
Righteousness is characteristic of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's obedience shows his righteousness
Jesus Christ judges righteously
Jesus Christ is declared not guilty
Jesus Christ's righteousness recognised by others
Consequences of Jesus Christ's righteousness
God justifies believers on account of the righteousness of Jesus Christ
All who believe share in the righteousness of Jesus Christ
Believers live by and for Jesus Christ's righteousness

primaryrefs.comment: One of Paul's prayers for Christians.

children.title: Jesus Christ, sinlessness of
children.comment: The complete absence of sin, only in Jesus Christ. Christ demonstrated complete obedience to God in spite of his human frailty, enabling him to be a perfect atoning sacrifice and to give his righteousness to sinners.

children.title: Jesus Christ fully experienced human weakness
Jesus Christ was tempted to sin
Jesus Christ resisted the temptation to sin
Jesus Christ committed no sin
He only spoke the truth
He fulfilled the law
He was fully obedient to his human parents
He was fully obedient to his heavenly Father
He was innocent according to Roman law
Jesus Christ's sinlessness was recognised by others
Jesus Christ was perfect
Jesus Christ's sinlessness qualified him to be the perfect sacrifice

children.title: Jesus Christ's sinlessness is the grounds of believers' sanctification
Jesus Christ, sonship of
children.comment: Jesus Christ is described as Son of David, Son of Man and Son of God. His sonship speaks of his divinity and humanity and is closely associated with his role as promised Messiah, suffering Saviour, risen Lord and coming judge and king. It also speaks of his intimate, obedient and unique relationship with his Father and of his mission to enable people to become children of God through faith in him.

children.title: Jesus Christ as the Son of David
He is physically descended from David
He is the promised royal Messiah of David's line
He is both the Son and Lord of David
Jesus Christ as the Son of Man
Jesus Christ as the Son of God
His divine origin and divinity
His intimate relationship with the Father

primaryrefs.comment: ``Abba'' was a term of intimacy and familiarity that children used with their own fathers.

His obedience to the Father's mission

primaryrefs.comment: One of the major themes of John's Gospel is that Jesus Christ is glorified through his death and resurrection.

His appearance
He receives glory from all creation

At the end of time
Jesus Christ, grace and mercy of
children.comment: The qualities of Jesus Christ by which he is compassionate, accepting and generous. In his ministry, Christ demonstrates these qualities towards those whom he encounters. Believers should model themselves upon Jesus Christ in this respect.

children.title: The grace and mercy of God made known in Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ shows the grace of God in his life.

Jesus Christ responds to pleas for mercy

the parable of the good Samaritan

The grace and mercy of Jesus Christ and the Christian life
The need to rely upon the grace of Jesus Christ
Prayers for the grace of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ, holiness of
children.comment: The holiness of Jesus Christ is seen in his divine nature and work, as he stands apart from and above the created world with divine power, authority and purity. Recognition of the holiness of Jesus Christ leads both to a realisation of sin and unworthiness and to worship and adoration.

children.title: The holy character of Jesus Christ
Its divine origin
Its divine nature
Its divine purity
Its divine power
The holy work of Jesus Christ
He is set apart as God's servant
His life is consecrated to the will and purpose of God
He is appointed as the judge of sinners
He makes God's people holy
Declarations of the holiness of Jesus Christ
Results of recognising the holiness of Jesus Christ
Awareness of sin and unworthiness
Fear
Adoration and worship
Jesus Christ, humanity of
children.comment: Scripture stresses the total humanity of Jesus Christ. Although sinless, Christ shared in the general condition of humanity, including suffering and death.

children.title: Jesus Christ was a man
By his own claims
In statements made by others

seealsos.comment: the centurion
the Pharisees and teachers of the law
some Jews

children.title: Jesus Christ shared in the general condition of humanity
He assumed human nature

primaryrefs.comment: ``flesh'' here speaks not only of a material body but also of human nature.

children.title: He had a human descent
He had a normal body which could be handled and touched
He had a soul
Jesus Christ partook of human experience
He was born
He grew and developed
He was hungry
He was thirsty
He was tired
He slept
He was tempted
He suffered
He died

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ most closely identified with the rest of humanity through his death. However Jesus Christ is distinct from human beings in that his death was an act of free will and not the inevitable consequence of sin (see Jn 10:17-18).

children.title: The risen Christ has human characteristics
The returning Christ retains his human identity
Jesus Christ was a sinless human being

primaryrefs.comment: Sinlessness does not make Jesus Christ less human. It is sin that degrades humanity.

children.title: The necessity of Jesus Christ's humanity
As a man Jesus Christ made atonement for sin
As a man Jesus Christ gives the gift of resurrection
As a man Jesus Christ is able to help others in their need
As a man Jesus Christ is the perfect example
Jesus Christ, humility of
children.comment: The obedient submission of Jesus Christ to his Father, seen in his willingness to become a human being for humanity's sake, his freedom from self-interest and his willingness to serve others.

children.title: Jesus Christ's willingness to become a human being

primaryrefs.comment: ``human likeness'' is not mere similarity to but identity with humanity.

children.title: Jesus Christ's humility predicted in the OT
The poverty of Jesus Christ's birth and upbringing

secondaryrefs.comment: Only the poorest families offered doves or pigeons.

Jesus Christ's dependence on his heavenly Father

Jesus Christ's humility as a model for others
Jesus Christ, joy of
children.comment: Jesus Christ brings joy to his people, who are able to rejoice at the coming of their Saviour and Lord, and all the benefits which he brings to them.

children.title: Jesus Christ's joy originates in God
From his intimate relationship with his Father and the Spirit
From his awareness of God's purposes
Jesus Christ's coming brings great joy
His birth
His resurrection and ascension

Being in his presence is likened to the joy of a wedding
To know Jesus Christ brings great joy to others
Jesus Christ, justice of
children.comment: The teaching and lifestyle of Jesus Christ show him to be just and impartial in his judgments and dealings with people. At the end of the age, God has appointed Jesus Christ to judge and rule with justice.

children.title: Justice was a quality displayed in Jesus Christ's life
Jesus Christ was just and impartial in his dealings with people

secondaryrefs.comment: with tax collectors and those classed as ``sinners''

Jesus Christ will judge the nations with justice

children.title: Jesus Christ will rule the nations with justice

seealsos.comment: This prophecy refers to the Messianic age when Jesus Christ will rule the world as king

children.title: Jesus Christ, knowledge of
children.comment: Jesus Christ has perfect insight into God's purposes and into human nature by reason of his intimate relationship with the Father, but he has accepted limited knowledge as a consequence of his humanity.

Jesus Christ's complete knowledge

Jesus Christ, love of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's total giving of himself, shown supremely in his obedient suffering and death on the cross, reveals God's amazing love for sinners. It continues to motivate and inspire Christians today.

children.title: The supreme quality of Jesus Christ's love
It caused him to leave his eternal glory
It moved him to give his life for others

His love inspires a desire for spiritual gifts

Jesus Christ, majesty of
children.comment: The glorious splendour of Jesus Christ's royal authority belongs to him by right and is reaffirmed through his exaltation to the Father's right hand.

children.title: Jesus Christ shared in God's majesty before time began
Jesus Christ renounced his majesty to become a human being

At the transfiguration

Jesus Christ, mind of
children.comment: The centre of Jesus Christ's thought, understanding and motivation, characterised by a total dedication to God. Christians are called upon to have the same mind as Christ.

children.title: The intellectual capacity of Jesus Christ's mind
In childhood
In adulthood
Jesus Christ's mind was pure

primaryrefs.comment: The purity of Jesus Christ's mind is declared by his words and actions and by his oneness with God.

children.title: Examples of Jesus Christ's use of his mind

Against opposition

Jesus Christ, obedience of
children.comment: The selfless obedience of Jesus Christ to the will of God his Father, through which the redemption of humanity is accomplished. Christ also shows himself willing to submit to earthly authorities and sets an example which believers are called to imitate.

children.title: Jesus Christ was totally obedient to his Father's will
Obedience was central to Jesus Christ's life and thought
Jesus Christ's obedience meant ultimate personal cost
Jesus Christ's obedience was necessary for God's salvation plan
Jesus Christ's obedience was shown in his human relationships
He was obedient to his parents
He was obedient to secular authorities
He was obedient to the Jewish law

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's obedience and commitment were to the spirit of God's law; his attitudes to Jewish legalism were often seen as disobedience.  Disputes over the Sabbath are one example.

children.title: Believers should follow Jesus Christ's example of obedience
Obedience to God's will is paramount
Christlike obedience expresses love for God
Obedience should characterise believers' lives

primaryrefs.comment: ``obedience'' refers to a whole lifestyle arising from a relationship with God through Jesus Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ, patience of
children.comment: Jesus Christ supremely displays God's patient character in his work of salvation. The patience of Jesus Christ is seen in his relationships with people and in his perseverance through trial and suffering to death. Followers of Christ are called to demonstrate patience in all their relationships and circumstances.

children.title: The patience of Jesus Christ in his earthly ministry
His patience with people
His patience with God's timing of events

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's life was lived under the shadow of the cross. He was concerned that people should understand his ministry and therefore he exercised great patience, being directed by the Father in the priorities and timing of his ministry.

children.title: His patience in suffering
Jesus Christ reflects God's own patient character
Jesus Christ's patience brings about God's salvation
Jesus Christ's patience must be appropriated by his followers
In relation to people
In enduring life's circumstances and sufferings
In communicating the gospel
In living and waiting for the Lord's coming
Examples of Jesus Christ's patience found in his followers
Jesus Christ, perfection of
children.comment: Jesus Christ perfectly radiates the glory of God, exactly representing his Father's likeness. Christ's work is complete and he is free from all impurity.

children.title: Jesus Christ represents perfection and absoluteness
His perfection was established through obedient suffering
All things find fulfilment in Christ
Jesus Christ radiates God's glory

seealsos.comment: At the transfiguration Jesus Christ's face mirrors God's glory and purity

children.title: Jesus Christ exactly represents the Father's likeness
The fulness of God dwells in Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's work is totally complete
Christians will finally participate in Christ's perfection
Jesus Christ is without impurity
Jesus Christ, power of
children.comment: The historical and ongoing effective authority of Jesus Christ over natural elements, over human life and ultimately over sin, forces of evil, Satan and death.

Jesus Christ's power remains available in human experience
Jesus Christ's forgiving power is effective today
Jesus Christ's enabling power is effective today
Jesus Christ, pre-eminence of
children.comment: Jesus Christ excels over all of creation and reigns supreme over everthing in the created order.

Over all people
Over his enemies

primaryrefs.comment: By so saying Jesus Christ applied this verse to himself. The capstone/cornerstone was the most significant stone of a building's structure.

children.title: He is the Chief Shepherd

His divine origin
His equality with the Father
His authority derives from the Father
He possesses the rights of the firstborn

primaryrefs.comment: As the firstborn son has the rights and privileges of an heir, so Jesus Christ is heir of all things by virtue of his pre-existence and sonship.

children.title: He has a superior name
He is the First and the Last

primaryrefs.comment: This title implies that all things are summed up in Christ and find their purpose in him.

His resurrection

Jesus Christ, righteousness of
children.comment: Jesus Christ pleased his Father perfectly in his life on earth and in his death. He now gives believers a new status before God and a new power for living.

children.comment: The complete absence of sin, only in Jesus Christ. Christ demonstrated complete obedience to God in spite of his human frailty, enabling him to be a perfect atoning sacrifice and to give his righteousness to sinners.

Jesus Christ, sonship of
children.comment: Jesus Christ is described as Son of David, Son of Man and Son of God. His sonship speaks of his divinity and humanity and is closely associated with his role as promised Messiah, suffering Saviour, risen Lord and coming judge and king. It also speaks of his intimate, obedient and unique relationship with his Father and of his mission to enable people to become children of God through faith in him.

children.title: Jesus Christ as the Son of David
He is physically descended from David
He is the promised royal Messiah of David's line
He is both the Son and Lord of David
Jesus Christ as the Son of Man
Jesus Christ as the Son of God

His intimate relationship with the Father

primaryrefs.comment: ``Abba'' was a term of intimacy and familiarity that children used with their own fathers.

seealsos.comment: His baptism
